'pthread_mutex_t *' (aka 'struct _opaque_pthread_mutex_t *')
[-Werror,-Wformat-pedantic]

column20:
Fix verifier null-deref bug
Verifier threads were not setting the timer resulting into a null-deref crash when first call to timer_gettime() from verifier thread.
Fix memory leak
Detected with valgrind under the Android OS platform

column20:
Following same steps as in Linux arch, clear crash filename in case existing crash detected. This is required so that fuzz loop can understand we've hit a duplicate and thus not invoke verifier against that crash.
Also don't bother wasting time into constructing filename buffers if blacklisted hash detected - abort early.
column21:

column20:
Thanks to latest Android NDK r11 current honggfuzz codebase can be cross-compiled with clang3.6 toolchains using latest API 23 (Marshmallow). With some tuning it might be possible to support API 21 & 22 too (Lollipop), although for the moment I don't thing it's worth it.
The tricky bit was libBlocksRuntime since it's not part of the NDK. The AOSP llvm compiler-rt sources haven been copied across (without any changes to the source code) to statically cross-compile BlocksRuntime (just generated an Android.mk for the lib). For the time being BlocksRuntime needs to be updated manually, although compatibility is not expected to break for same clang version. Maybe we can add some update automation later when NDK starts supporting clang 3.7
More details are available in commit logs.

column21:
@tl0gic ,
I think that having such large file names is not practical. A normal MAC crash name is around 100chars already without the original seed name. Having that appended too makes it very hard to read (specially for cases like mine where I tend to put lot's of info in seeds names).
I've created a new PR (#71) which adds report file support for MAC arch. A sample report log looks like the following (ORIG_FNAME cover the information you wanted):
$ ./honggfuzz -f examples/inputfiles/badcode1.txt -N50 -q -r 0.0002 -V -- examples/targets/badcode1 ___FILE___
...
$ cat HONGGFUZZ.REPORT.TXT
=====================================================================
TIME: 2016-05-07.12:50:52
=====================================================================
FUZZER ARGS:
 flipRate     : 0.000200
 externalCmd  : NULL
 fuzzStdin    : FALSE
 timeout      : 10 (sec)
 ignoreAddr   : 0x0
 memoryLimit  : 0 (MiB)
 targetPid    : 0
 targetCmd    : (null)
 wordlistFile : NULL
 fuzzTarget   : examples/targets/badcode1 ___FILE___
ORIG_FNAME: badcode1.txt
FUZZ_FNAME: ./SIGSEGV.EXC_BAD_ACCESS.PC.00007fff85b100a5.STACK.00000015e2834b8f.ADDR.0000000000000000.fuzz
PID: 79475
SIGNAL: SIGSEGV (11)
EXCEPTION: EXC_BAD_ACCESS
FAULT ADDRESS: 0x0
CRASH FRAME PC: 0x7fff85b100a5
STACK HASH: 00000015e2834b8f
=====================================================================
=====================================================================
TIME: 2016-05-07.12:50:54
=====================================================================
FUZZER ARGS:
 flipRate     : 0.000200
 externalCmd  : NULL
 fuzzStdin    : FALSE
 timeout      : 10 (sec)
 ignoreAddr   : 0x0
 memoryLimit  : 0 (MiB)
 targetPid    : 0
 targetCmd    : (null)
 wordlistFile : NULL
 fuzzTarget   : examples/targets/badcode1 ___FILE___
ORIG_FNAME: badcode1.txt
FUZZ_FNAME: ./SIGSEGV.EXC_BAD_ACCESS.PC.00007fff85b100a5.STACK.00000014e6e3db0b.ADDR.0000000000000000.fuzz
PID: 79496
SIGNAL: SIGSEGV (11)
EXCEPTION: EXC_BAD_ACCESS
FAULT ADDRESS: 0x0
CRASH FRAME PC: 0x7fff85b100a5
STACK HASH: 00000014e6e3db0b
=====================================================================

It would be nice to add the crashing thread call stack in the log (as it's done in Linux ptrace arch), although due to how crash information is collected in MAC, it needs some (painful) manual string parsing as I mention in the commit log. Unfortunately, I don't have time to do it at the moment.

column20:
Has the same volume of information as the Linux ptrace arch, except the crashing frame stack traces. Since on MAC that information is available from crash wrangler as a huge description string, it needs some manual (and painful) string parsing and thus is not implemented yet.
If for some reason that information is required, users can enable file logging and compile with debug flag where the write_crash_report() function will be activated and write entire crash dump in file log.
This PR is also removing the recently added original seed filename info in crash file name, since it creates very large names are not very practical and might get truncated due to size limits. That information is available in the report now.

column20:
Has the same volume of information as the Linux ptrace arch, except the crashing frame stack traces. Since on MAC that information is available from crash wrangler as a huge description string, it needs some manual (and painful) string parsing and thus is not implemented yet.
If for some reason that information is required, users can enable file logging and compile with debug flag where the write_crash_report() function will be activated and write entire crash dump in file log.
This PR is also removing the recently added original seed filename info in crash file name, since it creates very large names are not very practical and might get truncated due to size limits. That information is available in the report now.

column13: Fix race condition when writing the report.
column20:
With more than 1 threads fuzzing it is possible to end up with a garbled report file.
To reproduce this I tried with a high number of threads (>10) and ended up with a report that looked like this:
=====================================================================
TIME: 2016-05-09.21:47:15
=====================================================================
FUZZER ARGS:
 flipRate     : 0.001000
 externalCmd  : NULL
 fuzzStdin    : FALSE
 timeout      : 10 (sec)
 ignoreAddr   : 0x0 
 memoryLimit  : 0 (MiB)
 targetPid    : 0 
 targetCmd    : (null)
 wordlistFile : NULL
 fuzzTarget   : examples/targets/badcode1 ___FILE___ 
=====================================================================
TIME: 2016-05-09.21:47:17
=====================================================================
FUZZER ARGS:
 flipRate     : 0.001000
 externalCmd  : NULL
 fuzzStdin    : FALSE
 timeout      : 10 (sec)
 ignoreAddr   : 0x0 
 memoryLimit  : 0 (MiB)
 targetPid    : 0 
 targetCmd    : (null)
 wordlistFile : NULL
 fuzzTarget   : examples/targets/badcode1 ___FILE___ 
ORIG_FNAME: badcode1.txt
FUZZ_FNAME: ./SIGSEGV.EXC_BAD_ACCESS.PC.00007fff9b0e70a5.STACK.00000014e6d38d7d.ADDR.0000000000000000.fuzz
PID: 27291
SIGNAL: SIGSEGV (11)
EXCEPTION: EXC_BAD_ACCESS
FAULT ADDRESS: 0x0 
CRASH FRAME PC: 0x7fff9b0e70a5
STACK HASH: 00000014e6d38d7d
=====================================================================
ORIG_FNAME: badcode1.txt
FUZZ_FNAME: ./SIGSEGV.EXC_BAD_ACCESS.PC.00007fff9b0e70a5.STACK.00000015e2b31df9.ADDR.0000000000000000.fuzz
PID: 27271
SIGNAL: SIGSEGV (11)
EXCEPTION: EXC_BAD_ACCESS
FAULT ADDRESS: 0x0 
CRASH FRAME PC: 0x7fff9b0e70a5
STACK HASH: 00000015e2b31df9
=====================================================================

Notice how the first crash is actually split in half.

column20:
Adds callstacks in OS X reports.
This is just a copy of the callstack as formatted by CrashWrangler. It would be nice to have it in exactly the same format as Linux but this requires parsing the description returned by CrashReport.
It looks like this:
=====================================================================
TIME: 2016-05-09.22:11:56
=====================================================================
FUZZER ARGS:
 flipRate     : 0.000200
 externalCmd  : NULL
 fuzzStdin    : FALSE
 timeout      : 10 (sec)
 ignoreAddr   : 0x0
 memoryLimit  : 0 (MiB)
 targetPid    : 0
 targetCmd    : (null)
 wordlistFile : NULL
 fuzzTarget   : examples/targets/badcode1 ___FILE___ 
ORIG_FNAME: badcode1.txt
FUZZ_FNAME: ./SIGSEGV.EXC_BAD_ACCESS.PC.00007fff9b0e70a5.STACK.0000000cd74e8a54.ADDR.0000000000000000.fuzz
PID: 28545
SIGNAL: SIGSEGV (11)
EXCEPTION: EXC_BAD_ACCESS
FAULT ADDRESS: 0x0
CRASH FRAME PC: 0x7fff9b0e70a5
STACK HASH: 0000000cd74e8a54
STACK: 
0   libsystem_c.dylib                   0x00007fff9b0e70a5 flockfile + 4
1   libsystem_c.dylib                   0x00007fff9b0e75fd feof + 15
2   badcode1                            0x0000000107327e2b output + 91
3   badcode1                            0x0000000107327ef2 main + 82
4   libdyld.dylib                       0x00007fff954335ad start + 1
=====================================================================

column20:
[../honggfuzz-master/sancov.c:454]: (error) Common realloc mistake: 'mapsBuf' nulled but not freed upon failure
This solution from Stack Overflow was helpful in fixing the error because if realloc cannot find enough space, it returns a null pointer, and leaves the previous region allocated.
Found by https://github.com/bryongloden/cppcheck

column21:
I think that cppcheck is not picking the defer blocks thus missing the free() calls triggered when function loses scope. For both reported cases the code inside the defer block will trigger the mentioned heap buffer frees. As such, I believe that they're both false positives.
I've run with valgrind under Android and haven't noticed any reported leaks. Do you have any different evidence from any memory inspection tool? If such, it means that defer blocks are not working as expected under certain cases / setups?

column20:
Checking ../honggfuzz-master/files.c: __clang__...
[../honggfuzz-master/files.c:144]: (error) Memory leak: buf
[../honggfuzz-master/files.c:371]: (error) Memory leak: inFileBuf
Found by https://github.com/bryongloden/cppcheck
column21: The defer construct is new to us, but if it's triggered after losing scope, it's logical that memory will be freed in both cases. We've had to adopt some unsound techniques in our tool because sound and complete static analysis is shown to be undecidable. Notwithstanding the logic of defer, manual inspection should have detected this false positive. Our apology for not catching that. Valgrind is a dynamic analysis tool, cppcheck is not. No other security testing tools were used for this bug scan.

column13: [ANDROID] Typo in makefile for arm-v7a clang toolchain
column20:
When toolchains upgraded to match Android NDK r12 format (clang version removed from toolchain suffix), a small typo for the armeabi-v7a target was resulting into wrongly choosing the GCC 4.9 toolchain when CLANG flag was enabled.
anestisb@nemesis:[honggfuzz]: ndk-build NDK_TOOLCHAIN=?
Android NDK: NDK_TOOLCHAIN is defined to the unsupported value ?
Android NDK: Please use one of the following values: aarch64-linux-android-4.9 aarch64-linux-android-clang arm-linux-androideabi-4.9 arm-linux-androideabi-clang mips64el-linux-android-4.9 mips64el-linux-android-clang mipsel-linux-android-4.9 mipsel-linux-android-clang x86-4.9 x86-clang x86_64-4.9 x86_64-clang
/Users/anestisb/Developer/android/android-ndk-r12b/build/core/init.mk:613: *** Android NDK: Aborting    .  Stop.

column21:
Thanks... so I'll take the display patch which is awseome.
But, I don't think I'll add -llzma to Makefile. I know that it might fix some problem, but I personaly think that the problem lies somewhere else.
We don't use lzma directly, and all libraries needing it (like unwind-ptrace) should depend on it, like here.
$ ldd /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libunwind-ptrace.so.0
...
liblzma.so.5 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/liblzma.so.5 (0x00007f5fed86c000)
...
If your library don't depend on it, then it's a bug, and I think the library compilation for your system should be fixed. Otherwise we'll be linking (and requiring) in lzma always, no matter whether it's needed or not.
Would you be willing to investigae why/if your libunwid is compiled correctly, and eventually asking Ubuntu maintainers for a fix (if needed)?

column13: [Android] Adjust makefile for NDK R13 compatibility
column20:
GCC compatibility is deprecated across the entire Android ecosystem
including the provided NDK toolchains. As explained in R13 changelog
GCC is no longer supported, although not remove yet [1].
Since CLANG toolchains are the new defaults, adjust makefile selection in
order to be aligned with ANDROID_CLANG flag value and be backwards
compatible with older NDKs that include GCC version 4.9
Honggfuzz was defaulting to GCC and both unwinding & ptrace backends
have been heavily tested against it. CLANG was also supported, although
not tested at the same extend. As such don't default to CLANG for now
until some more testing is performed.
[1] https://developer.android.com/ndk/downloads/index.html#rel

column13: Updated Makefile (on OSX) to use xcrun (from xcode) versus sw_vers t‚Ä¶
column20: ‚Ä¶o discover SDK version. This prevents failed builds when using OSX 10.11 with the newest Xcode 10.12.
column21:
I think this solution is not going to work in all instances.
OS_VERSION is used to determine which CRASH_REPORT to link into your binary. If you use the wrong one it won't build a proper binary for your OS X version.
What you need to change is SDK_NAME and for that I think it is a good idea to use xcrun --show-sdk-version instead of hardcoding the name as we do now.

xcrun doesn't give you the OS_VERSION. It is used to get the SDK version.
You should change SDK_NAME instead of OS_VERSION. Otherwise, if Apple releases a new CRASH_REPORTER your build will break.

column13: keep fuzzed file orig file ext
column20:
it can fuzzing the mulitple file format in the same time, for example, some image file(*.png, *.gif, *.jpg...) in the following file dir:
honggfuzz -f file -e any -- imageview ___FILE___
Some app must only parse the specific file suffix name.,but the default generated file suffix name is *.fuzz, and -e arg can only specify a file suffix, so the fuzzing would be invalid when input dir have multiple file suffix name.

column13: keep fuzzed file orig file ext
column20:
it can fuzzing the mulitple file format in the same time, for example, some image file(*.png, *.gif, *.jpg...) in the following file dir:

column21:
I don't think that all this overhead is necessary. If I'm not mistaken the fuzzed file extension has not been added with the concept of preserving the original extension. It's just a marker to separate mutated files from input corpus (keep in mind that not all runs have a meaningful file extension - e.g. external tools, stdin, etc.). To put it simply, .fuzz (or any other selected by the user) is an extension to identify files generated from honggfuzz regardless of the selected corpus.
Modifying the output extension will also break most post-fuzzing automation tools that rely on a constant suffix to pick-up fuzzer output crashes or dynamically generated files.
I don't see any practical reason for this overhead, since the generated fuzzer report includes the original seed file the mutation of which resulted into the matching crash.
So is there effectively any reason to dynamically modify the extension of output files?

Also forgot to mention that in case the fuzzing target expects the input files to be of a specific extension, you can utilize --pprocess_cmd option to rename files post mangling and before running the assigned worker.
-- edit
This will not work for file renaming since the file is expected to maintain the same assigned filename when reading the modified contents back to the buffer (see here)

column21:
I personally don't mix formats under same campaign when using honggfuzz since you don't get the best out of supported instrumentation backends.
Maybe another idea would be to differentiate the file extension of the intermediate files that are fed to the worker execve, from the file extension of the output crash files that will feed all post-campaign automation.
It's mostly politics, although it doesn't feel good to add this performance overhead for every file selection iteration without getting something substantial out of this paid cost.

column20:
On the top of NDK Android targets depend on capstone & libunwind for the ptrace() API arch backend. So far the build bash scripts were manually fetching upstream repos, applied local patches if required and initialized a CC cross-compile env to build them. This wasn't very efficient when deps were required to be updated.
As such git submodules mechanism has been utilized to automate dependencies handling. Submodule heads have been set to last heavily tested version for both projects (which is also effectively the latest stable for both).
On the top of the submoduling step, post-checkout client hooks are automatically registered from the build scripts for each module. Hooks ensure that after every new submodules checkout the previous generated .a files are invalidated, forcing the user to recompile against updated codebase.
Android doc page has been also updated with all recent compatibility versions & makefile options.

column13: Fix submodule init bug when non-recursive clone
column20:
When user clones repo without submodules, by default most
git versions appear to create just an empty directory for them. As
such just checking if directory present to init submodules is not
enough. Checks have been upgraded to use the presence of
projects' .git dir as an indicator for missing submodule initialization.
column21:
When user clones repo without submodules, by default most
git versions appear to create just an empty directory for them. As
such just checking if directory present to init submodules is not
enough. Checks have been upgraded to use the presence of
projects' .git dir as an indicator for missing submodule initialization.

column20:
libhfuzz is compiled as static library using the BUILD_STATIC_LIBRARY
template from Android NDK. The static library is added as "virtual"
dependency to main honggfuzz module, otherwise the build system
will ignore it since it detects that the module target is not used. The
libhfuzz extra cflags are matching the ones from master Makefile. Testing
of the libhfuzz is still pending since it requires clang 4.0 while Android is
still defaulting to 3.8.
Also tided-up a little bit the Android.mk so that common configuration is
shared at the top of the file for both target modules.
Finally an additional post build step was required to copy the generated
.a file into the project dir so that both output files are under the same file.
Static libraries compiled from NDK templates are not automatically added
to project output dirs since they purposed for internal dependencies by
default.
Added an extra 'android-all' rule to compile all supported ABI targets at
once. Supported flags are passed-through the make subprocesses so
that same level of control is achieved.

column20:
Android makefile should use APP_PLATFORM
ANDROID_API is not always visible for Android.mk, thus not safe to be used. Prefer APP_PLATFORM which is always set due the way ndk-build is invoked from master makefile.
Fix force clean sequence bug
If target Android API level changed from previous build, an initial clean will be triggered. However, due to the way that make expands expressions at first run, the file check for NDK toolchain config file will be also true while the file will have been deleted from triggered clean. This effectively triggers a shell cat against a missing file resulting into an ugly warning being print.
To avoid using secondary expansion, use a simple bool variable which checks if a clean has already happened before re-trying the checks against a different config.
column21:

However, due to the way that make expands expressions at first run, the file check for NDK toolchain config file will be also true while the file will have been deleted from triggered clean. This effectively triggers a shell cat against a missing file resulting into an ugly warning being print.
To avoid using secondary expansion, use a simple bool variable which checks if a clean has already happened before re-trying the checks against a different config.

column13: Linux symbols filters + proc maps DSO resolve
column20:
Symbol filters
For some of my use cases with jemalloc under Android I want to treat all crashes as unique when top frames contain symbols from allocator functions. The stackhash approach is most of the times good enough, although not always, resulting into few crashes being missed (specially in Android due to bionic many function proxy layers).
To cover this case (+blacklist per symbol when stackhash is not enough due to type of corruption e.g. function pointer) the concept of symbol filters (blacklist/whitelist) is implemented.
User can set filters with --linux_symbols_bl or --linux_symbols_wl options which expect an input file with one symbol per line. Simple wildcard (end of string only) case is also supported (e.g. files_*).
When whitelisted symbol is detected it has priority over both stackhash blacklist & symbol blacklist filters. When blacklisted symbol is detected the global blacklist crashes counter is also increased.
For now this featue is only enabled for Linux since for macOS the stack traces info is obtained from a single char buffer passed from crash wrangler. If such feature is desired a manual string parsing walkthrough needs to happen against the g_fuzzer_crash_callstack buffer.
proc maps DSO resolve
Utilize proc maps to extract the matching map path and include it at report stack traces. When crash is detected from an interesting signal (not ASan report parsing post exit), target pid proc maps is parsed once when unwinder is initialized and saved in a local list (heap). Then list is iterated from every resolved frame to extract the matching map name based on frame's ip address. The fact that proc map is sorted helps speeding-up search since we can early abort when matching map not found.
generic changes

funcs_t array is now stored in heap instead of stack since there was a considerable size overhead when the map name (PATH_MAX * max_number_of_frames) attribute has been added to the struct.
Update usage doc to include new cmd args
Comments around how funcs_t frame data is utilized for all supported unwind cases.

The failure:
$ honggfuzz -f in/ --linux_perf_bts_block -- /usr/bin/tiff -D FILE
[2016-11-11T23:11:20+0000][W][5951] arch_perfOpen():223 mmap(mmapAuxBuf) failed,
try increasing the kernel.perf_event_mlock_kb sysctl (up to even 300000000): Cannot allocate memory
[2016-11-11T23:11:20+0000][E][5951] arch_perfEnable():261 Cannot set up perf for PID=5953 (_HF_DYNFILE_BTS_BLOCK)
[2016-11-11T23:11:20+0000][F][5951] arch_prepareChild():248 Couldn't enable perf counters for pid 5953
It seems aux data also needs WRITE permissions.
At least this change fixes startup for me.
Reported-by: Mateusz Lenik
Signed-off-by: Sergei Trofimovich siarheit@google.com

[android] Fix wrong linking with libhfuzz.a from main tool
column20:
libhfuzz is not an actual dependency of the honggfuzz standalone tool. Instead it
is simply desired to always build it with the build config matching the main tool so
that it is available to user for wrapping targets with instrumentation.
Having libhfuzz as part of LOCAL_STATIC_LIBRARIES effectively instructs NDK
automation to include it as dependency. This results into resolving some of the
external libc dependencies (strcmp, strstr, etc.) with the ones implemented from
libhfuzz. This is not desired since it breaks functionality.
Replace LOCAL_STATIC_LIBRARIES dependency with a proper APP_MODULES
list when invoking ndk-build to always build both modules.

column20:
Separate sanitizers env config from sanitizers coverage
Refactor SIGABRT monitor logic & sanitizers exit-code strategy
Export flags to control sanitizers + SIGABRT
Simplified the sanitizer env preparation
Fixed small bugs around sanitizers logic

Commit messages & comments inside sanitizers.c provide a detailed insight of the changes. Most of the spotted bugs (missing crashes) were affecting targets were SIGABRT was not monitored.
Current changes have been heavily tested against latest Android 7.1 using Android NDK R13b.

column20:
Fixes a void return expression issue when compiling with clang. Issue was
spotted against macOS and was introduced by commit
d51cd3f
libhfuzz/instrument.c:182:9: error: void function '__sanitizer_cov_trace_cmp' should not return void expression [-Werror,-Wpedantic]
        return __sanitizer_cov_trace_cmp1(Arg1, Arg2);
        ^      ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
libhfuzz/instrument.c:184:9: error: void function '__sanitizer_cov_trace_cmp' should not return void expression [-Werror,-Wpedantic]
        return __sanitizer_cov_trace_cmp2(Arg1, Arg2);
        ^      ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
libhfuzz/instrument.c:186:9: error: void function '__sanitizer_cov_trace_cmp' should not return void expression [-Werror,-Wpedantic]

column20:
when building packages (e.g. for openSUSE Linux)
(random) filesystem order of input files
influences ordering of functions in the output,
thus without the patch, builds (in disposable VMs) would always differ.
See https://reproducible-builds.org/ for why this matters.

column13: Do not setenv("OPENSSL_armcap") if OPENSSL_ARMCAP_ABI is zero
column20:
It seems like we always set OPENSSL_ARMCAP_ABI -- but on newer versions with BoringSSL, this is not necessary (per the docs).  However, the variable is still set and appears to override OPENSSL_armcap_P in the BoringSSL source.
We should change this so that we can build without -DOPENSSL_ARMCAP_ABI=X (since it shouldn't be needed on newer Android builds) and avoid the setenv call entirely.
column21:

We should change this so that we can build without -DOPENSSL_ARMCAP_ABI=X (since it shouldn't be needed on newer Android builds) and avoid the setenv call entirely.

column13: android: NDK r16 compatibility & switch default to clang
column20:
Android NDK r16 deprecates (although doesn't remove yet) the gcc 4.9 support.
However, some toolchain flags have been altered thus need the
ANDROID_NDK_TOOLCHAIN_VER flag to be also set to effectively select gcc
over default clang.
This commit is also switching the default compiler selection from gcc to clang. It
has been tested the past few months and no issues surfaced so far against
various aarch64 Android targets.

column13: Fix issues on Android system builds
column20:
Bionic's implementation of strcmp() is hijacked by Honggfuzz, and invoked before
either Address Sanitizer or the trace-pc-guard coverage initialization routines
have been invoked.
This leads to segfaults on Android builds with ASAN+coverage.
Use trace_pc_guard as a convenient place to check for ASAN's initialization.
Defer trace_pc_guard activity until coverage is initialized.
Change-Id: I1dfa1946b8baad1ac58f39917d59b74ffd25bdd4

column13: Support external fuzzer and provide code coverage
column20:
Aka The FFW honggfuzz patch.
This proposed patch for honggfuzz is used by the fuzzing for worms (FFW) framework available here: github.com/dobin/ffw
This patch makes it possible to use honggfuzz as a code coverage tool for long-living (network-) servers.
It provides the following functionality:

A socket interface for an external fuzzer
Support for code coverage of long living processes

The socket interface supports the following messages:

Honggfuzz -> Fuzzer: "Fuzz": Send fuzz data to target
Honggfuzz -> Fuzzer: "Cras": Target crashed
Honggfuzz -> Fuzzer: "New!": New basic block reached
Fuzzer -> Honggfuzz: "okay": Fuzzer sent his stuff to target
Fuzzer -> Honggfuzz: "bad!": The server is unreachable

Honggfuzz will implement the following tasks:

Start the target
Restart the target if it crashes
Restart the target if a crash/hang is detected by the fuzzer
Provide code coverage information about new basic blocks

An example vulnerable server plus tests have been provided in the
socketfuzzer/ directory.

column21:
Main problems which i tried to solve in the honggfuzz codebase:

Identify when a process is crashed
Identify when a process needs to be restarted

Shortcomings:

The unit test socketfuzzer/unittest.sh will fail regularly and randomly. It appears like the new basic block identification is not reliable (HF bug?)
Identification of crashes in HF is performed in trace.c and arch.c. There should be an easier, reliable way?
had to introduce a variable "hasCrashed", to indicate that the long living process is crashed (either detected by HF, or by the fuzzer / externally)
The unit test will fail  if the binary is compiled with HFUZZ_CC_ASAN
I cannot compile the unit tst atm with hfuzz-clang, only hfuzz-gcc

While this patch works for me, i dont feel the quality is adequate to integrate it into honggfuzz. Feedback is welcome.

column13: WIP: port persistent fuzzing to macOS
column20:
This is very basic and hfuzz-cc doesn't work yet but it's enough to make honggfuzz-rs work.
About the setrlimit patch, I choose a very basic solution which is maybe not the best.
The recommended way to set NOFILE to the maximum on macOS is to set it to MIN(OPEN_MAX, rlim_max) but OPEN_MAX is deprecated and undefined on Linux. There is also FOPEN_MAX but it is usually set to a very low value: 16 (the minimum guaranteed value by Posix). I also tried other solution but none of them were satisfactory and portable.
But anyway, in our case, we only need a limit of 1024 (here is my evidence: https://github.com/google/honggfuzz/blob/master/honggfuzz.c#L86) so I choose the easy solution to set the limit this value directly.
About arch_reapChild, since the old version contained no specific macOS logic, I copied to code from the posix version and it works well.
The project now works with Rust code but hfuzz-cc fails to compile C/C++ code.
Here is the error I get on High Sierra:
paulg@Pauls-iMac ~/Projects> ./honggfuzz/hfuzz_cc/hfuzz-cc -v test.c 
Apple LLVM version 9.0.0 (clang-900.0.39.2)
Target: x86_64-apple-darwin17.4.0

column21:
This is very basic and hfuzz-cc doesn't work yet but it's enough to make honggfuzz-rs work.
About the setrlimit patch, I choose a very basic solution which is maybe not the best.
The recommended way to set NOFILE to the maximum on macOS is to set it to MIN(OPEN_MAX, rlim_max) but OPEN_MAX is deprecated and undefined on Linux. There is also FOPEN_MAX but it is usually set to a very low value: 16 (the minimum guaranteed value by Posix). I also tried other solution but none of them were satisfactory and portable.
But anyway, in our case, we only need a limit of 1024 (here is my evidence: https://github.com/google/honggfuzz/blob/master/honggfuzz.c#L86) so I choose the easy solution to set the limit this value directly.
About arch_reapChild, since the old version contained no specific macOS logic, I copied to code from the posix version and it works well.
The project now works with Rust code but hfuzz-cc fails to compile C/C++ code.
Here is the error I get on High Sierra:

This is very basic and hfuzz-cc doesn't work yet but it's enough to make honggfuzz-rs work.

If your company signed a CLA, they designated a Point of Contact who decides which employees are authorized to participate. You may need to contact the Point of Contact for your company and ask to be added to the group of authorized contributors. If you don't know who your Point of Contact is, direct the project maintainer to go/cla#troubleshoot. The email used to register you as an authorized contributor must be the email used for the Git commit.
In order to pass this check, please resolve this problem and have the pull request author add another comment and the bot will run again. If the bot doesn't comment, it means it doesn't think anything has changed.

column13: WIP: port persistent fuzzing to macOS
column20:
This is very basic and hfuzz-cc doesn't work yet but it's enough to make honggfuzz-rs work.
About the setrlimit patch, I choose a very basic solution which is maybe not the best.
The recommended way to set NOFILE to the maximum on macOS is to set it to MIN(OPEN_MAX, rlim_max) but OPEN_MAX is deprecated and undefined on Linux. There is also FOPEN_MAX but it is usually set to a very low value: 16 (the minimum guaranteed value by Posix). I also tried other solution but none of them were satisfactory and portable.
But anyway, in our case, we only need a limit of 1024 (here is my evidence: https://github.com/google/honggfuzz/blob/master/honggfuzz.c#L86) so I choose the easy solution to set the limit this value directly.
About arch_reapChild, since the old version contained no specific macOS logic, I copied to code from the posix version and it works well.
The project now works with Rust code but hfuzz-cc fails to compile C/C++ code.

column13: Makefile: On Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), build as Posix
column20:
The Linux specific parts of honggfuzz are too specific to work on WSL but the Posix version works well.
This change uses the internet "de facto" way of detecting WSL (ie: uname -r) to condition the compilation.

column20: The errorcodes returned by libipt functions are returned as negative numbers. We need to flip them back to positive before passing them to pt_errstr (otherwise we get 'internal error' every time).

column20:
Using -pthread instead of -lpthread flag
Add install option for make
Convert char type to unsigned char type before calling isdigit(3)
and tolower(3). Because according to the ctype(3) man page of NetBSD,
the parameter of these functions should be representable as unsigned
char to avoid undefined behaviors. For more details, please refer to:
http://netbsd.gw.com/cgi-bin/man-cgi?ctype+3+NetBSD-current

Thanks for your pull request. It looks like this may be your first contribution to a Google open source project (if not, look below for help). Before we can look at your pull request, you'll need to sign a Contributor License Agreement (CLA).

Once you've signed (or fixed any issues), please reply here (e.g. I signed it!) and we'll verify it.

What to do if you already signed the CLA
Individual signers

It's possible we don't have your GitHub username or you're using a different email address on your commit. Check your existing CLA data and verify that your email is set on your git commits.

Corporate signers

Your company has a Point of Contact who decides which employees are authorized to participate. Ask your POC to be added to the group of authorized contributors. If you don't know who your Point of Contact is, direct the Google project maintainer to go/cla#troubleshoot (Public version).
The email used to register you as an authorized contributor must be the email used for the Git commit. Check your existing CLA data and verify that your email is set on your git commits.
The email used to register you as an authorized contributor must also be attached to your GitHub account.

From a NetBSD developer point of view, this patch looks correct.
There is a nit that some symbols are called _symbol, it's a reserved namespace in the NetBSD libc and they will clash.. like _strcasecmp.

column21:
Perfect!
While there, are there some tests for the ptrace(2) attach functionality? I intend to port it to NetBSD, it would be nice to have some aid to know whether it works as expected with feature parity with Linux.
We have got an odd use-case of fuzzing the ping(8) program.. maybe there would be an option to attach to a running ping(8) program and feed it with randomized ICMP content.
So far traditional integration of AFL, honggfuzz, libFuzzer and radamsa over some C API failed to get integration without massive code rewrite.

column21:
Hm.. the ptrace code is quite Linux specific, even assuming some emulation in NetBSD (I guess it's similar to FreeBSD's?).
There are no automatic tests, I've been testing it manually with just few fuzzing setups I have (under Linux, MacOS and with FreeBSD).
As for ptrac'eing data into ping and other apps, this sounds viable technically, but you'd have to know the addresses, and run the app without ASLR, so not sure how many people would use this mode. Maybe it'd be more useful to create some LD_PRELOAD lib for ping which hijacks sendmsg or whatever is used with ping, and fills the buffer with fuzzed data?

column21:
NetBSD supports all the features used in ptrace(2) of honggfuzz natively... however the porting isn't straightforward. Some time ago I wrote this presentation to ease porting and comparison:
http://netbsd.org/~kamil/ptrace-netbsd/presentation.html
Hmm LD_PRELOAD is an interesting idea, I've overlooked it.. @plusun have you tried it?

column21:
Hi, I've tried to use LD_PRELOAD method together with HF_ITER interface. But I encountered some problems.
Here is my source code: https://github.com/plusun/src/tree/LD_PRELOAD/sbin/ping
The most important one is the fuzzer_ops.c, within which I shadowed some interfaces like socket, poll and etc. The most important one is recvfrom. They will call HF_ITER to fetch data and organize them into a structure.
With this setting, I compiled it into a library like this:

hfuzz-clang -fPIC  -Wall -Werror -g -c fuzzer_ops.c
hfuzz-clang -shared -fPIC fuzzer_ops.o /path/to/libhfuzz.a -o libfuzzerops.so

And then recompiled the ping(8) from source with hfuzz-clang and hf-clang++. But unfortunately, when I fuzz it with this command:

LD_PRELOAD=$PWD/libfuzzerops.so honggfuzz -P -f input/ -- ./ping -c 1 127.0.0.1

it got error like this:

Entering phase 1/2: Dry Run
Launched new fuzzing thread, no. #0
Launched new fuzzing thread, no. #1
Launched new fuzzing thread, no. #2
Launched new fuzzing thread, no. #3
Launched new fuzzing thread, no. #5
Launched new fuzzing thread, no. #4
Launched new fuzzing thread, no. #6
Persistent mode: Launched new persistent PID: 19225
Launched new fuzzing thread, no. #7
[2018-07-18T12:53:08+0000][F][18913] HonggfuzzFetchData():75 readFromFd(rcvLen, size=8) failed

There was an initial file containing a "hello, world" string under the input directory.
Could you please tell me what is happening with this error?
Thanks,
Yang Zheng

column21:
Do you have any warning before that, the readFromFd() should throw sth?
In any case, maybe your ping binary closes filedescriptors above some value (*BSDs have closefrom()), and honggfuzz uses 1021-1024, given that ping is set-uid?

Does it work without a sanitizer? Sanitizers open a lot of FDs on startup.
Please try to record execution of the process with ktruss -i -o log.dat $PROGRAM_HERE.
Probably we might want to wrap LD_PRELOAD=$PWD/libfuzzerops.so honggfuzz -P -f input/ -- ./ping -c 1 127.0.0.1 with a shell script to not overwrite dynamic symbols in ktruss(1).
After that, please share kdump log.dat.

column21:
This is a really great to know that LD_PRELOAD fuzzing works, I was thinkering how to perform something like fuzzing from the kernel syscall layer (like using PT_SYSCALL / PT_SYSCALLEMU) and get rid of ifdefs. I'm happy that we have managed to get a functional solution!
There is a GCE support done by @bsiegert.
Another option pmci: https://github.com/billziss-gh/pmci
There are some downstream relases as live-cd, but I propose to just install the pristine one in a VM:
http://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/NetBSD/NetBSD-8.0/images/NetBSD-8.0-amd64.iso
Proposed steps:

install the distribution including all sets
fetch pkgsrc from source
install security/mozilla-rootcerts (cd pkgsrc/security/mozilla-rootcerts && make install)
and follow post-install notes of mozilla-rootcerts
install git (devel/git): cd pkgsrc/devel/git && make install
install other programs, possibly: devel/gmake, shell/bash, lib/libBlocksRuntime

Snapshot this VM image and play with honggfuzz.
Regarding toolchain with sanitziers, this is an ongoing effort and my focus is the upstream trunk. Please ignore the sanitizers available in the distribution as of now.  This is an ongoing process of streamlining these tools to the Linux level ( https://wip.pkgsrc.org/cgi-bin/gitweb.cgi?p=pkgsrc-wip.git;a=blob;f=compiler-rt-netbsd/TODO.check;h=d5fa535ff188f95a54ddcb46264a5228b18ad4a6;hb=HEAD ). I'm using with @plusun a local pile of patches.
I'm working on micro-UBSan and if I will manage to get some spare time during this month, I will try to port ptrace(2) in honggfuzz to NetBSD. I've managed to run regression tests against uUBSan and catch thousands of reports.. http://netbsd.org/~kamil/mksanitizer-reports/atf-mklibcsanitizer-2018-07-25.txt this means I'm a little bit swamped.
(BTW. mail has been sent)

column21:
We are working on a follow up of the previous work and we would like to charge the fuzzed program on demand for the exact number of bytes from honggfuzz. Would the fuzzer be smart enough to support it?
We would like to avoid collecting a lot of data in a buffer before calling APIs and charge from it manually as it would be too slow and the buffer too large.

column21:
The interface HF_ITER/LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput is generally in charge of delivering bytes/length because it presumably has some strategy about what data should be fuzzed (also structure).
I don't mind adding fetching just random bytes if it serves some purpose, so I guess we could add your implementation of HF_MEMGET or something similar.
I guess you'd like though to change how honggfuzz statistics behave in such case, i.e. to increase counters only when HF_MEMGET returns?

column21:
I have no opinion on the counters. I just care whether the fuzzer is smart enough to handle a function like HF_MEMGET().
Another nice addition would be to allow to feed an application using HF_ITER()/HF_MEMGET() with a reproducer. Is there a simple way?

column21:
A nice addition to HF_MEMGET() would be to specify with a mask/flags what type of input is allowed. We have got a use-case of allowing e.g. characters valid in file names or in hex ascii numbers. Squashing all the input from a fuzzer is possible, but looks hackish.
A feature request is to pass input as argv[] parameters... but it is possibly for another discussion.

This all sounds reasonable, I don't feel personally the case for such set of functions too well, but it's just limitation of my imagination, I trust you on this one. Esp. if it's just some addition/modification of libhfuzz, then feel free to submit something.
The latter suggestions (beyond just HF_MEMGET()) would require me wrapping my mind around it, but I guess we can start with something simpler?

column13: Improve the portability of execvp(3) calls
column20:
Do not use hardcoded "cc" or "c++" as argv[0] passed to a compiler.
Some programs including clang on NetBSD try to determine the name of the
executed program by parsing the argv[0] parameter passed to main().
Add a wrapper hf_execvp() that sets argv[0] to the same value as the
first argument to execvp() with an executable filename.
This issue caused an error that Clang/LLVM was calling GCC through
the "cc" filename, and it was causing a fatal build issue.

column20:
Model this code after existing Linux backend and try to keep differences
to minimum.
Features and design choices, compared to the Linux code:

capstone dependency as a disassembler
no bfd support
-D_KERNTYPES for register_t type
no clone() support
no disable ASLR switch (personality)
no libunwind support, there is no port of HP libunwind version
no hardware assisted profiling aid support
traditional PT_ATTACH in place of 'seize' operation
poll(2) detecting of signals, instead of sigtimedwait(2) which
didn't work for unknown reasons
no cross-ABI support (i386 on amd64 host)
currently only amd64 and i386 support

Missing or incomplete features are subject for improvement.
Tested with NetBSD/amd64 8.99.23

column21:
Some observations:

This code shall be relatively simple to port to FreeBSD (but I've never installed that OS and won't do it myself). FreeBSD also has hp libunwind usable on amd64, as opposed to NetBSD today.
The generic code seems to be too much clobbered by Linux-specific code, such as reporting Linux specific fields or performing operations that might not make sense such as calling performance counter routines and printing as debug messages them on a !Linux host.
On the other hand Linux/NetBSD/POSIX code could be merged when applicable.

column13: Print proper Thread Id in logs on NetBSD
column20:
All threads on NetBSD have the same process id and distinct thread id.
Add a conditional compilation switch for NetBSD, to implement __hf_pid()
with NetBSD specific call to return the Thread ID, in NetBSD terminolog
LWP ID (ligth-weight process identification).

column13: Fixes for fuzzing on NetBSD with concurrent fuzzer-threads
column20:
Do not support fuzzing forkees and vforkees. Doing so is non-trivial
in the current design of the fuzzer, as there is need to call wait(2)
function dedicated for every forkee and vforkee in a thread. In the
context of fuzzing in multiple instances of multiple processes this
means that there is need a redesign of the threading/process model
and wait(2)ing every tracee with a dedicated thread or iteration step
in a loop (perhaps try kqueue(2)/kevent(2)?).
A wait(2)-like function called for WAIT_ANY caused gathering reports
from other fuzzer-threads and in the result abnormal hangs.
While there, do not discard SIGTRAP that is emitted by user, and pass
this signal to the tracee.

column20: I find there is not exist a custom mutator option for feedback data in honggfuzz, so I add an option for using external custom data mutator, which can be used for mutating files by custom logic instead of mutating by internal mutators. column13: Add support for external custom feedback data mutator command

column21:
I am not sure I understand what additional purpose is this providing over existing mutate_cmd option provide which allows specifying an external utility to fuzz an input. Couldn't this custom logic be already specified in the external fuzzer?

Well from the honggfuzz source code, mutate_cmd can be used in dry-run mode, but not suitable for feedback mode. This extension can provides the ability of mutating data from external utility directly with current feedback-positive input.

column20:
Some of the code rework in honggfuzz made the socketfuzzer work unrealiably. This PR fixes it by identifying if the fuzzed process has crashed, or is determined unresponsive by the external fuzzer, and restarts it correctly.
The corresponding unit test have been updated and its output made nicer.

it runs slower than the current slowest

column20:
PoC for qemu_mode.
I don't like AFL's way of building from a specific tarball + applying patches, but QEMU uses submodules so downloading from github as a zip doesn't work.
The idea for now is that I keep a QEMU repo where the honggfuzz branch is the current implementation.
AFL's way looks better for more stable stuff.
Let me know what you think.
If you want a more trusted pipeline, I'll do it like AFL does.
So far the coverage implemented is:

basic block
cmp

I'm instrumenting instructions in the disassembler. AFAIK that's the most stable and clean option. For x86 I just instrument cmps and on ARM a bunch of instructions. Unfortunately, t's difficult to understand what needs to be instrumented without some empirical data.
It would be nice to have some CI going on since QEMU is huge and complex but for now it seems to work ok.

column13: Added option to export the feedback struct to disk
column20: Hi, I added a new commandline option to export the feedback_t struct to disk. I'm using that so I can afterwards fairly conveniently visualize the fuzz coverage of a binary. I'm not sure if this is a useful feature in general, and it might also be somewhat problematic as it's now essentially exporting an implementation detail...

column20:
Commit 6271897 changed the name of the path at which a tmpfs is
mounted for the duration of a main program from "/tmp/FUZZ" to
"/tmp/HFND_TMP_DIR". This change adds a weak-linked function allowing
fuzzers to override the temporary directory, e.g.:
int HonggfuzzNetDriverTempdir(char *str, size_t size)
{
   return snprintf(str, size, "/tmp/foo.%d", getpid());
}

This is particularily useful when multiple users share a system and
shouldn't each other. A future change could make the code use
mkdtemp(3).
The default path remains "/tmp/HFND_TMP_DIR" and the "/tmp/FUZZ"
directory isn't affected by this change.

column20: Commit 0b418dd has already disabled ODR detection for honggfuzz invocations without "--sanitizers". This change does the same for when sanitizers are explicitly enabled. ODR violations aren't a concern for fuzzing, but rather for unit or integration tests.

column13: netdriver: Add support for non-TCP protocols
column21:
Would it be possible to rewrite it, so it maybe does the following.
socklen_t HonggfuzzNetDriverServerAddress(struct sockaddr** addr) {
[‚Ä¶]
This way we can avoid the input legtht problem, as it's basically the function owning the struct (which is in TLS, which is static, which can be used out of function scope).

I didn't want to make the client code the owner of the address storage and by returning the struct length as the return value it becomes impossible to return an error status (e.g. if the fuzzer has code that can fail for some reason).

Ok, done in 1ea443f
Would it be possible to implement your AF_UNIX connections on top of that?

I don't know without studying your changes in-depth. It's neigh impossible to say because the commit message doesn't describe the changes at a high level.
I know you own the code, but I spent considerable time working out an interface that works for fuzzing AF_UNIX and other non-TCP families without breaking compatibility with existing code and actually tested it (e.g. attempting to set TCP_NODELAY on AF_UNIX will fail). netDriver_waitForServerReady seems excessively repetitive. There was no clear need for a "rewrite".

column13: netdriver: Add support for non-TCP protocols
column21:
I'm sorry it turned out this way. My fault!
I'll try to improve on the github log messaging, and on discussing the pull request fronts.
To my defense, I felt like the old code structure was tied too much towards TCP, and even support for TCP/IPv6 was somewhat a hack.
I'll take a look at your original PR one more time, and try to implement the functionality you were looking for on my own, to avoid putting the burden of understanding the new code on you, I hope that's ok.

column13: netdriver: Add support for non-TCP protocols
column21:
FYI: I believe the needed functionality is now implemented by 6814cb6
If you're still interested in this code, please feel free to test it.
FWIW: I think that returning socklen_t might be a better option here. First, it's simpler, and simpler is typically better. I don't think we need error handling there. The HonggfuzzNetDriverServerAddress() should either return 0 (function not interested in setting address), or fail hard with panic() (LOG_F here). There's no recovery from error in this path. We shouldn't be trying to connect to default ports if HonggfuzzNetDriverServerAddress() fails, because it means that the code wanted the netdriver to something very specific, and failed to describe it.

QQ: Would you mind me changing the default path from ${tmpdir}/pipe to ${tmpdir}/sock or ${tmpdir}/socket
It's a bit bikeshedding on my part, but technically it is a socket and not a pipe.
Also.. we're currently supporting SOCK_STREAM only, and I've seen that samba sometimes uses SOCK_DGRAM with AF_UNIX (e.g. the samba-tool uses it). Do you think that supporting it would be useful?

column13: netdriver: Add support for non-TCP protocols
column21:
QQ: Would you mind me changing the default path from ${tmpdir}/pipe to ${tmpdir}/sock or ${tmpdir}/socket

Not at all. The code I'm working on is going to supply its own socket path anyway.

Also.. we're currently supporting SOCK_STREAM only, and I've seen that samba sometimes uses SOCK_DGRAM with AF_UNIX (e.g. the samba-tool uses it). Do you think that supporting it would be useful?

Yes, that would also allow fuzzing other protocols, e.g. DNS servers via UDP.

column21:
Sorry for late reply, I missed this.
The config idea sounds intriguing, it can actually also solve the problem of making local changes to the data (custom mutators?), as it can technically contain a function pointer to a mutator function, like the one that is described here: https://github.com/google/fuzzing/blob/master/docs/structure-aware-fuzzing.md
My personal TCP fuzzing cases don't require such heavy configuration, but I'm totally ok with enhancements, if your use-cases call for it.

column20:
Commit 6814cb6 made major changes and introduced the
"HonggfuzzNetDriverServerAddress" function which can be defined by
a fuzzer. Unfortunately the connection attempt didn't use the
fuzzer-provided length and thus truncated longer socket address
structures such as "sockaddr_un".

column13: netdriver: make it possible to specify both type (e.g. SOCK_DGRAM) and protocol for the destination address.
column20:
This requires change to the HonggfuzzNetDriverServerAddress()
declaration, as it needs to enable its users to specify those two
additional params.
Additionally, pass struct sockaddr_storage to
HonggfuzzNetDriverServerAddress(), as this will prevent this func for
owning storage for the used sockaddr. It was not a bug, but this
semantics should be more familiar for C coders.

column21:
It seems to be a bug in libunwind's package under ubuntu, changing the libs from the current
-lunwind-ptrace -lunwind-generic -lunwind
to pkgconfig
`pkg-config --libs libunwind-ptrace libunwind-generic`

doesn't help
$¬†CFLAGS="-fuse-ld=lld" make clean all
...
ld.lld: error: /usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-linux-gnu/9/../../../x86_64-linux-gnu/libunwind-ptrace.so: undefined reference to lzma_stream_buffer_decode
ld.lld: error: /usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-linux-gnu/9/../../../x86_64-linux-gnu/libunwind-ptrace.so: undefined reference to lzma_index_uncompressed_size
ld.lld: error: /usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-linux-gnu/9/../../../x86_64-linux-gnu/libunwind-ptrace.so: undefined reference to lzma_index_end
ld.lld: error: /usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-linux-gnu/9/../../../x86_64-linux-gnu/libunwind-ptrace.so: undefined reference to lzma_index_buffer_decode
ld.lld: error: /usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-linux-gnu/9/../../../x86_64-linux-gnu/libunwind-ptrace.so: undefined reference to lzma_stream_footer_decode
ld.lld: error: /usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-linux-gnu/9/../../../x86_64-linux-gnu/libunwind-ptrace.so: undefined reference to lzma_index_size
The problem is that lubunwind-ptrace.so doesn't require liblzma
$ ldd /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libunwind-ptrace.so.0.0.0 
	linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007fffc5ba2000)
	libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f38c62f8000)
	/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f38c6514000)
but
$ ldd /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libunwind-generic.so
..
	liblzma.so.5 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/liblzma.so.5 (0x00007ff0aacfb000)
..

does. If lld is picky about order of shared libraries, we can change the order of dynamic libs manually, from
-lunwind-ptrace -lunwind-generic -lunwind
to
-lunwind -lunwind-generic -lunwind-ptrace

$ CFLAGS="-fuse-ld=lld" make clean all
..all good..
Technically it's libunwind's job to require lzma if they use it, either through DT_NEEDED in ELF, or via proper pkgconfig file. I guess we can live with the temporary patch (reversing order of unwind libs), but I wouldn't require -lzma as it might not be required by some version of libunwind, so it'd be an unnecessary dependency.
Thanks for bringing it up, please feel free to test at HEAD or with 5def7f0

column13: Makefile: fix compilation dependency on macOS
column20:
On a clean tree, when running make, mac/mach_excServer.c and
mac/mach_excUser.c were not yet generated by the mig command.
They were therefore not included in ARCH_SRCS and therefore neither
in SRCS nor OBJS and then were not compiled and not included in the
final binary, which made the compilation fail.
A previous solution to avoid this problem was to run make twice so that
the generated .c files are correctly included in ARCH_SRCS at the
second run.
This patch explicitly adds thoses two files as object file targets when
building on macOS and then ajusts compilation targets to make everything build
correctly.
thanks to @shamatar for reporting the issue:
rust-fuzz/honggfuzz-rs#35

column13: Fix sort verification for blacklist entries
column20:
blacklist.txt
8
1
2

Honggfuzz doesn't complain this file isn't sorted, because the first entry is ignored.
blacklist.txt
3
2
1

Honggfuzz correctly warns input_parseBlacklist():310 Blacklist file not sorted.
The first entry gets ignored because the sorting check won't trigger until there are 2 or more entries (because the counter is updated after the comparison).
306 input.c:
        if (hfuzz->feedback.blacklistCnt > 1) {
            if (hfuzz->feedback.blacklist[hfuzz->feedback.blacklistCnt - 1] >
                hfuzz->feedback.blacklist[hfuzz->feedback.blacklistCnt]) {

The only values that will be checked for sorted order will be indexes (1) and (2) and every line higher, the index (0) is never checked.

column13: Mutex not initialised leads to crash in MacOS for honggfuzz 2.2 while fuzzing
column20:
While testing on MacOS 10.15.4, honggfuzz (latest/HEAD) crashes before completing the dry run, with the following message.
2020-05-03T17:02:27+0530][F][87320] util_mutexLock():280 fuzz_setDynamicMainState():95 pthread_mutex_lock(0x107c44228): Undefined error: 0

Initialising the .state variable fixes this and was able to get it running.

column20:
The -o argument was not working:
> /path/to/honggfuzz -z -P -i working-corpus/ -o hftmp -- ./target            
/home/jpereyda/code/honggfuzz/honggfuzz: invalid option -- 'o'
Usage: /home/jpereyda/code/honggfuzz/honggfuzz [options] -- path_to_command [args]
Options:
 --help|-h 
        Help plz..
[...]

But --output did work:
> /path/to/honggfuzz -z -P -i working-corpus/ --output hftmp -- ./target

After this code change, the following works:
> /path/to/honggfuzz -z -P -i working-corpus/ -o hftmp -- ./target

Root cause was a missing entry in the optstring argument to getopt_long

column13: make --output dir if it doesn't exist, as already done with -W
column20:
Running honggfuzz with -o and -W where neither directory exists:
> ls | grep hftmp
> /path/honggfuzz -z -P -i working-corpus/ --output hftmpo -W hftmpW -- ./target
[...]
[2020-05-07T09:47:51-0700][F][11897] main():331 Output directory 'hftmpo' is not writeable: No such file or directory
> ls | grep hftmp
hftmpW

Only the -W directory is created.
After code change:
> ls | grep hftmp
> /path/to/honggfuzz -z -P -i working-corpus/ -o hftmpo -W hftmpW -- ./target
[...fuzzing output...]
> ls | grep hftmp
hftmpo
hftmpW

column20:
Stop using install -t as it is GNU specific. Replace it with a
portable construct.
Before reading with ptrace(2) from address 0x0, check whether
the VA0 is mappable into the process, as otherwise the ptrace(2)
call will return EINVAL.
Stop intercepting fork(2) events as they are ignored anyway.
Document PTRACE_POSIX_SPAWN events.
Use PT_SET_SIGPASS to disable notifying the parent about
uninteresting signals. The only interesting ones are crash signals,
SIGABRT and SIGSYS. Everything else is directly passed to the
traced process.

column13: delete some wmb calls to get more speed
column20:
This PR is for #346
I delete some wmb calls which may be unnecessary, since there are atomic operations already.
I use libxml2 for test,  and use F 1 to make a comparable test:
./honggfuzz -i in -F 1 -- ./examples/libxml2/before_patch speed: about 13000 15000/s
./honggfuzz -i in -F 1 -- ./examples/libxml2/after_patch speed: about 15000 17000/s

column20:
This PR is related to #345
It's still WIP....
I use libxml2 for test, and use -F 1 to make a comparable test (Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-8750H CPU):
./honggfuzz -i in -F 1 -t 10 -- ./examples/libxml2/before_patch speed: about 15000 to 17000/s
./honggfuzz -i in -F 1 -t 10 -- ./examples/libxml2/after_patch speed: about 21000 to 22000/s
and in single thread mod, it has much more improvement
./honggfuzz -i in -F 1 -t 10 -n 1 -- ./examples/libxml2/before_patch speed: about 4500/s
./honggfuzz -i in -F 1 -t 10 -n 1-- ./examples/libxml2/after_patch speed: about 8000 to 8500/s
The basic Idea is to not scan binary each time, but use a binary search way to determine if a value exists in the binary....
Becasue It need a time-consuming initialize stage to get sorted values of binary... So it's only suitable for persistent mode...
Do you have any ideas about where should I start to make this idea work with fork-modeÔºü@robertswiecki

That may be the reason that it have more improvement, comparing to previous research mentioned in #345.

column21:
I change some of the code, so the idea for now is:

cache all 32/64 bit readonly-values.
when util_xxbitValInBinary is called, it first check whether v is in read-only value set
if it's not read-only set, we return to original way -- scanning the binary, but only within writable segments.

Using libxml2 test case, it still have a big speed improvement,
./honggfuzz -i in -F 1 -t 10 -- ./examples/libxml2/after_patch speed: about 21000 to 22000/s
./honggfuzz -i in -F 1 -t 10 -n 1-- ./examples/libxml2/after_patch speed: about 7800 to 8000/s

column21:
@robetrtswiecki
Thank you for your response!
As I mentioned before.. this pr is still work in progress due to the time-consuming stage that collect values and sort them.
This stage takes more than 1.5 second on libxml2, but only need to run only once. It is currently done in the instrumented code in fuzzed binary, so the first run will takes much more time.
As a consequence, timeout must be set to 2 for libxml2, and maybe more for other targets.
If you think this is a critical problem, you can just revert this pr. I will continue on this PR, moving it to fuzzing engine from instrumented code, to solve this problem..

column20:
If we run in fork-and-exec mode, staticCnt will starts
from zero for each run. So for example __sanitizer_cov_trace_cmp4 will
only be executed at the 4096th time...
If the target is small to have 4096 cmp during execution,
__sanitizer_cov_trace_cmp4 trick will never work.
Even if the target is big, instrumentLimitEvery is may still biased....
So I just make it random..

column20:
The specific problem I was running into is that the socket fuzzer was running out of memory when dynfile->data was being allocated in input_addDynamicInput as run->dynfile->size was whatever had been on heap. (There's likely other good reasons to initialize the memory though.)
In addition, remove --sancov from the documentation as it's been removed from the code.

column20:
Hi! Here is a patch that may be useful for others.
Honggfuzz offers a way to plug an external mutator, the --mutate_cmd command-line option. The main drawback of this approach is its cost. Honggfuzz creates a new process each time it invokes the external mutator.
This patch addresses this issue. It adds a new option: --custom_mutator <SHARED-OBJECT>. When this option is present, Honggfuzz will call the mutator passed as parameter. The performance achieved with this new patch is the same as the Honggfuzz's internal mutators since there is no need to create a new process.
The mutator has to export a function called custom_mutator with the following prototype:
void custom_mutator(uint8_t *buf, size_t len);
NOTE: Tested on Ubuntu.

column20:
Hi! Here's a small patch to log some of the stats to disk that may be useful to others.
It adds a new command line option: --statsfile <FILENAME>. It logs the following data in CSV format:
unix_time, last_cov_update, total_exec, exec_per_sec, crashes, unique_crashes, hangs, edge, pc

The logging is done every time new coverage is found.

column13: Added support for IP compression when using --linux_perf_ipt_block
column20:
Add support for IP compression when using Intel PT for hardware-based coverage-feedback fuzzing
When using Intel PT for hardware-based coverage-feedback fuzzing (with the --linux_perf_ipt_block option), IP compression is ignored (see Intel¬Æ 64 and IA-32 Architectures Software Developer‚Äôs Manual Vol. 3C Section 35.4.2.2 "Target IP (TIP) Packet"). As a result, there will be many collisions in the coverage bitmap.
This issue is also mentioned in this README by the developers of libxdc:

Hongfuzz: Similarly to PTrix, honggfuzz avoids disassembling the stream and instead only considers the contend of the TIP packages. It should be noted that it seems like the authors ignored TIP compression and hence cause a significant amount of collisions in the bitmap.

To support IP compression, the latest IP emitted by TIP, TIP.PGE and TIP.PGD Intel PT packets is tracked using last_tip_ip.

column20:
While --save_all can be used to save all crashes, often people only
really want to find the smallest possible crash file.
This patch adds a --save_smaller option that overwrites the crash file
when it would shrink the file size.
See #305
This is currently LINUX ONLY.

column13: android target under OSX / android aarch64 libunwind patches
column20:
This PR fixes the following:

android build of libunwind and libcapstone under OSX would fail due to hardcoded "linux" in toolchain path (#381)
libunwind with ptrace enabled for android/aarch64 would fail during runtime for the following reasons:

HAVE_DECL_PTRACE_POKEUSER was enabled while HAVE_DECL_PT_GETREGSET was disabled. This would cause unw_init_remote to return EBADREG, as a result making every crash appear unique when it clearly wasn't. This config was correct in previous versions of honggfuzz (file: compile-libunwind.sh) but was removed in ac7df4e
Preprocessor branch on HAVE_DECL_PT_GETFPREGS (file src/ptrace/_UPT_access_fpreg.c) did not properly exclude aarch64 resulting in the wrong implementation of _UPT_access_fpreg being compiled in.
column21:

android build of libunwind and libcapstone under OSX would fail due to hardcoded "linux" in toolchain path (#381)

column13: android target under OSX / android aarch64 libunwind patches
column20:
This PR fixes the following:

android build of libunwind and libcapstone under OSX would fail due to hardcoded "linux" in toolchain path (#381)
libunwind with ptrace enabled for android/aarch64 would fail during runtime for the following reasons:

HAVE_DECL_PTRACE_POKEUSER was enabled while HAVE_DECL_PT_GETREGSET was disabled. This would cause unw_init_remote to return EBADREG, as a result making every crash appear unique when it clearly wasn't. This config was correct in previous versions of honggfuzz (file: compile-libunwind.sh) but was removed in ac7df4e
Preprocessor branch on HAVE_DECL_PT_GETFPREGS (file src/ptrace/_UPT_access_fpreg.c) did not properly exclude aarch64 resulting in the wrong implementation of _UPT_access_fpreg being compiled in.

column13: FreeBSD cpu activity aggregation fix for FreeBSD.
column20:
By default, the cpu shows no activity as the proc filesytem is
not mounted by default on this platform, therefore relying on native api
to aggregate the data.

column13: Fix default/debug build with Bazel on OSX
column20:
For debug / fastbuild (default) Bazel defines DEBUG on OSX.
This is somewhat legacy, but Bazel developers consider that "works as intended".
Without this fix bazelbuild / rules_fuzzing project does not build on OSX.

column20:
CentOS 7 uses gcc 4.8.5, which fails to build with the following error
linux/trace.c: In function 'arch_traceSaveData':
linux/trace.c:545:5: error: missing initializer for field 'si_signo' of 'siginfo_t' [-Werror=missing-field-initializers]
     siginfo_t si                  = {};
     ^
In file included from /usr/include/signal.h:80:0,
                 from ./honggfuzz.h:31,
                 from ./linux/trace.h:29,
                 from linux/trace.c:24:
/usr/include/bits/siginfo.h:64:9: note: 'si_signo' declared here
     int si_signo;  /* Signal number.  */
         ^
linux/trace.c: At top level:
cc1: error: unrecognized command line option "-Wno-format-truncation" [-Werror]
cc1: all warnings being treated as errors
make: *** [linux/trace.o] Error 1

This MR detects this old version and initializes the struct accordingly

column13: cmdline: fail if command line can't be parsed
column20:
It should make it easier to integrate honggfuzz into CI.
Trying to integrate honggfuzz into the elfutils testsuite I
wrote a script running fuzz targets with hongfuzz for a couple
of minutes. It worked with honggfuzz built using the master
branch but when I switched to the latest stable version a test
that should have failed passed unexpectedly. The culprit was
--exit_code_upon_crash (which hasn't been released yet). If would
have been much easier to track that down if honggfuzz had complained
that it failed to parse the command line and exited with a non-zero
exit code.

Trying to integrate honggfuzz into the elfutils testsuite I
wrote a script running fuzz targets with hongfuzz for a couple
of minutes. It worked with honggfuzz built using the master
branch but when I switched to the latest stable version a test

column13: linux/trace: avoid explicit casts to struct user_regs_struct_*
column20:
Use union of struct user_regs_struct_32 and struct user_regs_struct_64
to avoid explicit casts to these structures.
Also, do not use struct pt_regs on powerpc and powerpc64.
References: #376
This is a PoC, feel free to reuse.
column21:

to avoid explicit casts to these structures.

column13: linux/trace: avoid explicit casts to struct user_regs_struct_*
column20:
Use union of struct user_regs_struct_32 and struct user_regs_struct_64
to avoid explicit casts to these structures.
Also, do not use struct pt_regs on powerpc and powerpc64.
References: #376
This is a PoC, feel free to reuse.
column21:
Thanks, this is a good idea (the union). I used it in cd77e53 in a slightly different implementation. Thanks for the hint.
I tested the chaneg with x86/x86-64/ppc64/arm64/arm32 - but sadly no access to mips for now.

column20:
Hi Robert,
recently, I created go-hfuzz for a project of mine.
Here's a PR to add it to the readme.
Like my python-hfuzz, this does not instrument any code.
It's just glue code to use libhfuzz.a from go.
Ofc, feel free to close the PR if you don't feel like merging it ;)
Cheers!
P.S.: Also did s/python-fuzz/python-hfuzz.

I'm compiling on openSUSE Tumbleweed, I don't know if it's related?
If the patch is not appropriate and there is a specific configuration for that, feel free to close!
column21:
Thanks for debugging this. But this error you posted is a bit confusing. honggfuzz links with dynamic versions of libbfd and libopcodes, and they should be automatically managing dependencies.
Do you have dynamic versions of libbfd/libopcodes installed. E.g. with Debian testing it's in
$¬†dpkg -L libbinutils:amd64
...
/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libbfd-2.37.50-system.20220106.so
/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libopcodes-2.37.50-system.20220106.so
...

And those libs automatically pull in required libraries. E.g.
¬†$ ldd /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libbfd-2.37.50-system.20220106.so
	linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007ffed1716000)
	libz.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libz.so.1 (0x00007f67ec978000)
	libdl.so.2 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdl.so.2 (0x00007f67ec973000)
	libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f67ec76f000)
	/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f67ecb1e000)

I think the easiest solution would be to install dynamic binutils libs, if possible, under OpenSUSE. We could maybe use pkg-config instead, but it's not available for binutils with e.g. Debian. Simply adding additional libraries to the linker path might solve the problem for you, but might be problematic for someone, whose binutils don't depend on this lib, and this lib is not installed.
Can you check whether you have the following files on your system
libbfd*.so
libopcodes*.so

If so, could you run ldd on them?
PS:
If there're no libbfd.so and libopcodes.so on your system, could you check with the following, if honggfuzz compiles w/o your patch?
ln -s /usr/lib/libbfd-2.37.20211112-3.so /usr/lib/libbfd.so
ln -s /usr/lib/libopcodes-2.37.20211112-3.so /usr/lib/libopcodes.so

Maybe the symlinks are missing in openSUSE?

column13: Always build against libiberty and libz on Linux

I'll close the PR as I understand it's not an issue on your end.
